Question.Text: A 31-year-old HIV-positive man presents to a clinic with a 6-week history of fever, chills/sweats, cough, shortness of breath, fatigue and weight loss. He has a history of extensive work-related travel. He is febrile with type 1 respiratory failure

Answer: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) - The HIV-positive patient presents with subacute respiratory symptoms (6 weeks of fever, cough, dyspnea) and type 1 respiratory failure with extensive travel history. The images show chest X-ray with bilateral interstitial infiltrates and Pneumocystis jirovecii cysts on microscopy with characteristic disc-shaped organisms, the most common opportunistic pneumonia in AIDS patients.
